ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course provided an overview of issues regarding language use and social context. The first half of the course was relatively focused on large-scale language ideologies, and the relation between language use and presumed social unity/difference. The second half of the course focused on linguistic structure and kinds of speech via a classically linguistic anthropological approach. This course helped me unite my understanding of 'language ideology' in the abstract with the more fine-grained study of speech acts and their perceived value.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would wholeheartedly recommend this course to another student. It is set up to facilitate weekly discussions of the readings while you work on a final project throughout the semester. That said, it is best if you have some research topic in mind in advance, which the readings will then help you to theoretically frame.
